edu.biu.scapi.circuits.encryption

Interface MultiKeyEncryptionScheme

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    AES128MultiKeyEncryption, AESFixedKeyMultiKeyEncryption, HashingMultiKeyEncryption

    public interface MultiKeyEncryptionScheme
    A general interface for creating multiple key encryption schemes.

    When constructing a garbled circuit, an encryption scheme must be specified. The Garbled circuit will use the specified scheme to encrypt each gate.

    See Garbling Schemes by Mihir Bellare, Viet Tung Hoang, and Phillip Rogaway. In this paper, the authors present the idea of a Garbling Scheme--i.e. the notion to treat Garbling Schemes as cryptographic primitive. In the paper, they present a number of different efficient garbling schemes.

    We have implemented a number of the schemes that they mentioned, and any other garbling scheme can easily be implemented and used anywhere in our code as long as they implement this interface.

    Author:
    Steven Goldfeder

    • Method Detail

      • generateKey

        javax.crypto.SecretKey generateKey()
        This method generates a single NOT a MultiSecretKey.

        This is necessary since the user will often need to generate single keys first and then combine them to a single MultiSecretKey.

        Consider the following problem: Say we want to garble and compute a gate in Yao's protocol. Consider a 2 input gate. Each input Wire will have two possible garbled values--corresponding to a 0 value and a 1 value. These values are <@code SecretKey}s NOTMultiSecretKeys. When we encrypt the truth table, we combine the single keys to create MultiSecretKeys. So, if we want to encrypt the 0-0 entry of the truth table, we will take the 0 key from each GarbledWire and combine them to a MultiSecretKey (using the generateMultiKey() method. Then if we want to encrypt the 0-1 entry, we will use the 0-key from the first wire and the 1-key from the second wire. We will combine these 2 keys into a single MultiSecretKey and use this to encrypt. Note that in this example, the 0-key from the first Wire is combined from 2 different MultiSecretKeys. First we combined it with the 0-key of the second wire and then we combined it with the 1-key.

        Thus, it is necessary to have a method to generate individual keys and a separate method to combine different single keys into MultiSecretKeys.

        Returns:
        SecretKey of the specified size. One or more of these keys will be combined into a MultiSecretKey to encrypt and decrypt with.

      • generateMultiKey

        MultiSecretKey generateMultiKey(javax.crypto.SecretKey... keys)
        This method is provided with individual SecretKeys and combines them into a MultiSecretKey that can be used for encryption and decryption with the MultiKeyEncryptionScheme.
        Parameters:
        keys - The individual SecretKeys that make up the MultiSecretKey. The SecretKey objects can be passed in an array or as individual parameters.
        Returns:
        a MultiSecretKey made up of the SecretKeys that were passed as parameters.

      • setKey

        void setKey(MultiSecretKey key)
        Sets the key to the specified MultiKeyEncryptionScheme.

        The key that it is currently set to, will be used for encryption and decryption until setKey() is called again.

        Parameters:
        key - The MultiSecretKey to be used for encryption and decryption.

      • setTweak

        void setTweak(byte[] tweak)
        See Garbling Schemes by Mihir Bellare, Viet Tung Hoang, and Phillip Rogaway.

        Some encryption schemes use a tweak and instead of encrypting directly the entry of the plaintext, encrypt the tweak and then XOR the result with the plaintext.

        Some encryption schemes do not make use of a tweak, in which case calls to set the tweak have no effect. If you are implementing an encryption scheme that does not use a tweak, just leave the body of this method blank.

        Parameters:
        tweak - The tweak to be used for this encryption scheme.

      • encrypt

        byte[] encrypt(byte[] plaintext)
               throws KeyNotSetException,
                      TweakNotSetException,
                      javax.crypto.IllegalBlockSizeException,
                      PlaintextTooLongException,
                      java.security.InvalidKeyException
        This method used the individual SecretKeys that make up the MultiSecretKey to encrypt the plaintext.
        Parameters:
        plaintext - The plaintext to be encrypted.
        Returns:
        the ciphertext--i.e. the plainetext encrypted with the currently set key.
        Throws:
        KeyNotSetException
        TweakNotSetException
        java.security.InvalidKeyException
        javax.crypto.IllegalBlockSizeException
        PlaintextTooLongException

      • decrypt

        byte[] decrypt(byte[] ciphertext)
               throws CiphertextTooLongException,
                      KeyNotSetException,
                      TweakNotSetException,
                      java.security.InvalidKeyException,
                      javax.crypto.IllegalBlockSizeException
        Decrypts the ciphertext.
        Parameters:
        ciphertext - The ciphertext to be decrypted
        Returns:
        the plaintext--i.e. the ciphertext decrypted with the currently set key.

        javax.crypto.IllegalBlockSizeException

      • isKeySet

        boolean isKeySet()
        Checks if the key for this MultiKeyEncryptionScheme has been set.

        Returning true if it has been and false if it has not been.

        Before encrypting and decrypting, the key must be set.

        Returns:
        true if the key has been set, false otherwise.

      • getCipherSize

        int getCipherSize()
        Returns the size of the ciphertext.
